I think the bloat discussion between Colin and Derek has been 
great.  These issues definitely get to some of the fundamentals of 
NEAT, and it's good to think about them.  It's a credit to Derek and 
Philip that their paper spawned this discussion.  Ultimately I think 
a comparison between "phased" and "blended" runs may be in order, 
but I thought I'd give my 2 cents.  

Colin touched on what I'm about to say a bit but I want to say it 
more explicitly.    Bloat is a very tricky thing to pin down in 
NEAT.  Sometimes new structure enhances fitness immdiately, in wich 
case it isn't bloat, but what about new structure that doesn't 
change fitness at all?  Part of the reason for protecting innovation 
is of course to keep such stucture around for a while so it can 
optimize.  But then it's interesting that we are now discussing how 
best to cut it out.

That's not to say we don't want to do some pruning, but the question 
is how to measure how useful such pruning is.  In a simple problem, 
pruning (i.e. simplifying) rigorously may make sense, since if you 
cut something that would have been useful later, it's no big deal 
since it will probably reappear soon enough anyway.  However, in a 
really hard problem, you *need* structure to accumulate for a while, 
and pruning can undermine that process.

There is a sense in which "bloat" is an accomplishment, since it 
gets you into higher-dimensional space without a fitness penalty, 
and you may *need* to be in that space ultimately.  To the extent 
that your "bloated" solution works, you probably couldn't have 
gotten it to work in that larger space if you'd started in it 
directly, but now here you are in a more promising part of that 
space.  Obviously too much bloat is too much, but how much is too 
much?

We've observed runs in complex domains of thousands of generations 
in which fitness doesn't improve for hundreds of generations and 
then suddenly moves up, after which it climbs gradually for a while 
and then gets stuck again.  What's going on in a run like that?  In 
a normal GA, that phenomenon would be unlikely to see often, since 
you're probably stuck at a local optimum after hundreds of 
generations of stagnation, but in NEAT, it is able to build up some 
new structure slowly (because it requires slowly moving up 
complexity through new species and a little luck), and eventually 
the added structure sufficiently expands the space to do something 
that's actually novel, and voila you are no longer on a local 
optimum *even though* you haven't moved in space.  Instead, you've 
added new dimensions.

It's interesting to speculate which methodology, e.g. blended or 
phased, still allows such a dynamic to take place.  Anything that 
too aggressively cuts out structure that isn't immediately adding to 
function will undermine this potential.  It even brings up a 
question which Derek, Philip, and I have talked about in email, 
which is whether the nice results for blended runs also apply in 
very complex domains.  

I have little doubt that some simplification is a good thing, but I 
think we need to be cautious about how much we do it and how much 
it's really helping in the long haul even when it looks nice in the 
short run.  Protecting innovation is a long-term investment, and 
simplifying is to some extent short-term instant-gratification.  
Again, I'm not saying some degree of blending is bad, just that it's 
a deep issue.  As Derek pointed out, NEAT is meant to incrementally 
evaluate new structure, not add huge gobs of it at once, so there is 
another side to the argument.  Still, we do see some amazing escapes 
from stagnation that are clearly due to the accumulation of 
structure.

ken
